metadata.title: Statistically controlled biogenesis of silver nano-size by Penicillium chrysogenum MF318506 for biomedical application

sections.text:
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592
Available online 30 March 2020 1878-8181/© 2020 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Statistically controlled biogenesis of silver nano-size by Penicillium chrysogenum MF318506 for biomedical application
Abeer A. Abd El Aty a,*, Asem A. Mohamed a, Moustafa M. Zohair a,b, Ahmed A.F. Soliman c
a Chemistry of Natural & Microbial Products Department, Pharmaceutical Industries Research Division, National Research Centre, Dokki, Giza, 12622, Egypt b Nanomaterial Investigation Lab., Central Laboratories Network, National Research Centre, Dokki, Giza, 12622, Egypt c Drug Bioassay-Cell Culture Laboratory, Pharmacognosy Department, Pharmaceutical Industries Research Division, National Research Centre, Dokki, Giza, 12622, Egypt
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nano-size AgNPs Penicillium chrysogenum MF318506 Central composite design (CCD) Antimicrobial activity Cytotoxicity
A B S T R A C T
Biogenesis of metal nanoparticles draws significant attention due to environment eco-friendly and sustainable methods. Locally isolated Penicillium chrysogenum MF318506 free from mycotoxins was selected as candidate for bio-synthesis of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs). The response surface methodology (RSM) of central composite design (CCD) was applied to control the biosynthesis of silver nano-size and activity depending on the pH of the reaction mixture and AgNO3 concentration. Changing conditions in the design showed different nano-sizes with different antimicrobial and cytotoxic activities. The best conditions for biosynthesis of biologically active AgNPs could be attained using the low metal concentrations (0.172 and 1.0 mM) with high pH values (8, 12&10) after 6 h incubation in dark conditions. The controlled nanoparticles were studied and characterized by UV–visible spectrophotometry and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). From this study we have concluded that the statistically controlled silver nano-size from Penicillium chrysogenum MF318506 can be utilized as a novel good candidate in biomedical research.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nano-technology is one of the most effective and novel area of research in modern material science. This field of science is making a valuable impact in the life science, specially biotechnology and biomedical science (Gan and Li, 2012). Metal nanoparticles (MNP) introduce unique physical, chemical, electronic, and antimicrobial properties which make them suitable for their application in many fields including biosensing (Habouti et al., 2010), photonics (Hu and Chan, 2004), electronics (Alshehri et al., 2012), antimicrobials, anticancer (Salata, 2004; Chen et al., 2014) and in the biomedical fields for drug delivery and targeting (Cole et al., 2011; Sakamoto et al., 2010; Seigneuric et al., 2010). Silver nanoparticles are seemed to be one of the most valuable nanoparticles, that have been applied widely in different biomedical fields such as, cancer therapy, antimicrobial agent, anti-inflammatory factor and the delivery of drugs (Moghaddam et al., 2015; Vijayakumara et al., 2019).
Metal nanoparticles are commonly synthesized via the reduction of metal salts in a solution (Zhang et al., 2011) or the formation of metal atom aggregates by the heating or vaporization of a metal in inert gas or
vacuum (Tien et al., 2008). Size-controlled Ag NPs are also synthesized using new environment-friendly synthesis techniques (Mori et al., 2011). Recently, green synthetic approach for synthesis of non-toxic AgNPs using plant extracts like (leaves, flower, etc.), bacteria, fungi, and algae for the synthesis of nanoparticles offers a numbers of benefits of eco-friendliness and compatibility for pharmaceuticals and other biomedical applications, as they do not require toxic chemical for the synthesis process (Dhillon et al., 2012). Also the biogenic synthesis of metallic nanoparticles leads to the formation of capped nanostructures with proteins/biomolecules from the organism during the biosynthesis. These capping agents prevent nanoparticle aggregation and likely play an important role in the stabilization of the nanosystem. The presence of capping agents may improve the biocompatibility of biogenic nanomaterials (Seabra and Dur�an, 2015).
The application of fungal extracellular proteins has introduced an effective and a promising method for nanoparticles biosynthesis (Textor et al., 2010; El-Rafie et al., 2010; Sastry et al., 2004). Statistical designs of central composite (CCD) were recently used to optimize chemical or/and physical properties of nanoparticles, in this context the authors (Alivisatos, 1996; Bruchez et al., 1998; Coe et al., 2002) indicated that a
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: aabass44@yahoo.com (A.A. Abd El Aty).
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology
journal homepage: http://www.elsevier.com/locate/bab
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bcab.2020.101592 Received 20 January 2020; Received in revised form 24 March 2020; Accepted 27 March 2020
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592
wide spectrum of research has been oriented to control the size and shape, which is critical in controlling their chemical, physical and optical characteristics. Azam et al. (2012) emphasized that the toxicological action of AgNPs depends greatly on several factors including the producer organism, particles size and the tested pathogen. When AgNPs penetrate to the cytoplasm it may interface with the cell proteins, lipids and DNA lead to disruption of macromolecules inside the living cells or freeing of metal ions such as Ag þwhich may because interruption in the microbial metabolism leading to their death (Brunner et al., 2006).
There is a need for green approaches to obtain metal nanoparticles for biomedical and technological applications and to highlight the critical need to fully investigate the nanotoxicity of these particles. Therefore, the aim of this work is the biogenesis of statically controlled different sizes of AgNPs with varied biological activities using local fungal isolate. The response surface methodology (RSM) was used to find the most favorable experimental conditions like pH value and AgNO3 concentration for synthesis of ultrafine silver particles. Finally, an extensive screening study was conducted involving several pathogenic bacteria and fungi to identify a biological system for the different extracellular biosynthesized nano-sizes and their cytotoxic effects.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and materials
sections.text: Silver nitrate (AgNO3) was purchased from Sigma–Aldrich (Poole, UK). Standard mycotoxin (AFB1) was purchased from Sigma company analyses in vitro. Whatmann filter paper No.1 (Oakland, California, USA). Other reagents were all of analytical grade. Distilled water was employed for preparing all the solutions and reagents.

sections.heading: 2.2. Microorganism and its maintenance
sections.text: The fungus used for biosynthesis of nanoparticles was locally isolated from soil of Giza desert, Egypt. Stock cultures were maintained on potato dextrose agar (PDA) slant at 4 �C and sub-cultured routinely (Mostafa and El Aty, 2013).

sections.heading: 2.3. Molecular identification of the fungus
sections.text:
Preliminary identification of the fungal isolate was performed depending on the morphological characters of fungal culture in the Department of Chemistry of Natural and Microbial Products, National
α ¼ 1.41421.
A.A. Abd El Aty et al.
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592
Research Center, Egypt (Botton et al., 1985; Pitt and Hocking, 1985). In consistent with Abd El Aty et al. (2016) the molecular taxonomy was performed to validate and confirm the morphological identification and to study the phylogeny. The corresponding 18S rDNA of the strain was amplified by PCR using primers, ITS1 (50-TCC GTA GGT GAA CCT GCG G-30) and ITS4 (50-TCC TCC GCT TAT TGA TAT GC-30). Sequence data was analyzed in the GenBank database by using the BLAST program available on the National Center for Biotechnology Information website (NCBI). The nucleotide sequence of the strain was submitted to the GenBank and assigned specific accession number.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Extraction of AFB1 from liquid media
sections.text: AFB1 was extracted according to the method described by El-Banna et al. (1987). Extraction was carried out using 20 ml of chloroform (twice with 10 ml media), and homogenized for 3 min in a separation funnel. The chloroform phase was filtered through filter paper Whatman No. 3 and evaporated to dryness under a nitrogen stream.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Determination of AFB1 by HPLC
sections.text:
Derivatization: The derivatives of samples and standard were done as follow: 100 μl of trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) was added to samples and mixed well for 30 s and the mixture stand for 15 min 900 μl of water:
acetonitrile (9:1 v/v) were added and mixed well by vortex for 30 s and the mixture was used for HPLC analysis.

sections.heading: 2.5. Studying the different fermentation conditions affecting bio-synthesis of silver nanoparticles
sections.text: Two experiments were designed to select the best fermentation conditions for AgNPs biosynthesis, like the initial pH, incubation conditions, incubation period and inoculum size. The resulting solutions (AgNPs) were monitored using a UV–Vis spectrophotometer.

sections.heading: 2.5.1. Effect of initial pH and incubation condition
sections.text:
In the first experiment; the effect of different initial pH values (4, 6, 7, 8 and 9) with different incubation conditions (static or shaking at 150 rpm) were studied to select the best conditions for protein related to nitrate reductase and biomass production, important for biosynthesis of nanoparticles.
In this study, the slightly modified Czapek-Dox broth medium used which containing (in g/l): NaNO3 2.0, KH2PO4 1.0, MgSO4. H2O 0.5, FeSO4. 7H2O 0.001, Sucrose 20.0, and the initial pH was adjusted at 4, 6, 7, 8 and 9 before sterilization. For fermentation, one disc (6 mm diameter) of the actively growing seven days old culture was inoculated into 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask containing 50 mL broth media. The flasks have been incubated at 28–30 �C under static and shaking conditions
A.A. Abd El Aty et al.
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592
(150 rpm) for 7 days. At the end of incubation period, the mycelial biomass was separated by filtration using sterile Whatmann filter paper No.1 and the wet biomass were transferred into flask containing 50 mL sterile distilled water and incubated at the same conditions for 24 h. The final pH was recorded using (JENWAY, 3505 pH meter), dry weight and protein content were evaluated at different conditions after 24 h.

sections.heading: 2.5.2. Effect of incubation period and inoculum size
sections.text: In the second experiment; another two important factors affecting the biosynthesis of nanoparticles were studied, the incubation period (3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 days) and the inoculum size (1 and 2 discs). Czapek-Dox broth medium used with initial pH adjusted at 8, and all flasks were incubated under shaking conditions (150 rpm). The final pH, dry weight, protein content and AgNPs were determined as mentioned before.

sections.heading: 2.6. Bio-synthesis of silver nanoparticles
sections.text: The biosynthesis of AgNPs were evaluated in all experiments by mixing about 50 ml fungal extract with 0.5 ml aqueous solution of (0.58 mM AgNO3 stock solution). The mixtures were incubated in a 150 rpm rotating shaker at 30 �C for 5 days in dark conditions (Shaheen and Abd El Aty, 2018).

sections.heading: 2.7. Protein assay
sections.text: The protein concentration in the extracts used for preparation of nanoparticles was determined by the method of Lowry et al. (1951).

sections.heading: 2.8. Response surface methodology (RSM) application for controlled AgNPs–size and activity
sections.text:
RSM using central composite design (CCD) was applied to find out the best silver nitrate concentration and final pH value of the reaction mixture, that important for rapid synthesis of AgNPs with controlled size and shape. The independent variables selected for this study were, A: AgNO3 (mM) and B: Final pH.
Two–factors–5–levels central composite design (CCD) with 13 experiments, were carried out to determine the optimal values of (A) and (B). The two variables were investigated at low level (-1), zero level (0) and high level (þ1), respectively, with α ¼ 1.41421. Coded and actual values of variables and matrix of CCD along with maximum absorbance of biosynthesized AgNPs of each trial are shown in (Table 1).

sections.heading: 2.8.1. Statistical analysis
sections.text:
The Design-Expert® 8software from Stat-Ease, Inc. was used for regression and graphical analysis of the data obtained. The behavior of
A.A. Abd El Aty et al.
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592
the system was explained by the following quadratic model equation.
Y ¼ β0 þ β1Aþ β2Bþ β11A2þ β22B2þ þ β12AB
Where Y was the predicted maximum UV absorbance, β0; intercept, β1 and β2; linear coefficients, β11 andβ22; quadratic coefficients and β12; interactive coefficients. A and B were the independent variables corresponding to the concentration of AgNO3 (mM) and final pH respectively, Statistical analysis of the model was performed to evaluate the analysis of variance (ANOVA) that represented as contour plots (3D).

sections.heading: 2.9.1. UV–Visible spectroscopy
sections.text: AgNps biosynthesis was preliminarily confirmed by visual observation of color change from pale white to reddish brown. the absorption spectrum of fungal filtrate was scanned in the range of 200–800 nm on JASCO V-630 UV-VIS Spectrophotometer (JASCO INTERNATIONAL CO., LTD). The sharp peak given by UV visible spectrum has indicated the formation of AgNPs at the absorption range 400–450 nm.

sections.heading: 2.9.2. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM)
sections.text: AgNps have been characterized by TEM (JEOL-2100) to determine the size and shape of nanoparticles. The samples were prepared by dropcoating the AgNps solutions onto the carbon-coated copper grid and were loaded onto a specimen holder.

sections.heading: 2.9.3. Fourier transforms infrared spectroscopy (FTIR)
sections.text: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was used to detect the structural characteristic and functional groups of the fungal extract and nano-silver solution. The evaluation was done using FTIR spectrometer (JASCO, FT/IR- 6100), by employing KBr pellet technique. The spectra were scanned in the range of 400–4000 cm-1 at a resolution of 4 cm-1.

sections.heading: 2.9.4. Zeta-potential and particle size determination
sections.text:
Zeta potential and distribution of particle size were measured using Dynamic Light Scattering (Particle Sizing Systems, Inc. Santa Barbara, California, USA) in the range of 0.1–1000 μm.
A.A. Abd El Aty et al.
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592

sections.heading: 2.10. In-vitro antibacterial and antifungal activity study
sections.text:
Antimicrobial activity of the biosynthesized AgNps (1–5) were screened in-vitro against different pathogenic strains of Gram positive (Staphylococcus aureus ATCC29213) and Gram negative (Escherichia coli ATCC25922) bacteria, Fungi (Candida albicans ATCC10321, Candida tropicalis ATCC750, Aspergillus niger NRC53 and Fusarium solani NRC15) by the agar well diffusion technique according to Mostafa et al. (2016). Spores suspension of all strains were prepared and adjusted to be approximately (1 � 106 spores-ml of fungi and 1 � 108 of bacteria). 1 ml of fungal and bacterial spore suspensions was inoculated into each plate containing 50 ml of sterile potato dextrose agar PDA and nutrient agar medium NA, respectively. Wells of about (10 mm in diameter) were made in the solidified agar media and filled with 250 μl of AgNps colloidal solution, then they left for 120 min at room temperature for compound diffusion. The plates were incubated for 24 h at 30 �C for bacteria and 72 h at 28 �C for fungi. The inhibition zones of all tested organisms were recorded in millimeters at three different points and the average values are reported as Mean � SD using MS Excel (Abd El Aty and Ammar, 2016; Zohair et al., 2018).
Std. Dev. 0.73, R-Squared 0.8055, Mean 2.01, Adj R-Squared 0.6665.
A.A. Abd El Aty et al.
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592
A.A. Abd El Aty et al.
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592

sections.heading: 2.11.1. Cell culture
sections.text: HCT-116 (colorectal carcinoma) and MCF-7 (breast adenocarcinoma) were maintained in RPMI, DMEM medium (in case of HFB4). All media was supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum and incubated at 37 �C in 5 %CO2 and 95% humidity. Cells were sub-cultured using trypsin 0.15%. All cell lines were purchased from Viscera (Giza, Egypt).

sections.heading: 2.11.2. Cell viability assay
sections.text: After 24 h of seeding 20000 cells per well HCT-116, 10000 cells per well in case of MCF-7 and HFB4 cell lines (in 96 well plates), the medium was changed to fresh complete medium containing a final concentration of the extracts of 100 μg/ml in triplicates. The cells were treated for 48 h. 100 μg/ml doxorubicin was used as positive control and 0.5% DMSO was used as negative control. Cell viability was determined using the MTT (3-(4, 5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2, 5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) assay as described by Mosmann (1983). The equation used for calculation of percentage cytotoxicity: (1- (av(x)/(av(NC)))* 100.Where Av: average, X: absorbance of sample well measured at 595 nm with reference 690 nm, NC: absorbance of negative control measured at 595 nm with reference 690.

sections.heading: 2.11.3. Determination of IC50 values
sections.text:
In case of highly active samples the dose response study was made to calculate the IC50 value of each sample using probit analysis and utilizing the SPSS computer program (SPSS for windows, statistical analysis
software package/version 9/1989 SPSS Inc., Chicago, USA).

sections.heading: 3.1. Fungal isolate identification
sections.text: The morphological characteristics of the locally isolated fungus used in this study indicated that it was one of the Penicillium sp., according to (Botton et al., 1985; Pitt and Hocking, 1985). Sequence analysis of 18S rDNA of the fungal isolate with available NCBI GenBank database showed high similarity (99%) to Penicillium chrysogenum strain 8-5-F-11 (GeneBank accession number KR011761) and showed a close similarity (99%) with Penicillium chrysogenum strain 3-9-D-2 (GeneBank accession number KR011759) as shown in the phylogeny tree (Fig. 1). the selected isolate deposited in the GenBank under the name Penicillium chrysogenum and accession no. MF318506. The mycotoxins assay indicated that the fungal filtrate free from any carcinogenic mycotoxins.

sections.heading: 3.2. Controlled fermentation conditions for improved AgNPs biosynthesis
3.2.1. Effect of initial pH and incubation condition
sections.text:
Both of initial pH of the fermentation medium and the incubation conditions (static or shaking at 150 rpm) were important factors that were studied to select the best conditions for the fungal growth and production of protein related to nitrate reductase enzyme.
The results obtained (Fig. 2a) indicated that the fermentation medium prepared with initial pH 8 and incubated under shaking conditions (150 rpm) was the best for AgNPs biosynthesis, where the maximum UV–Vis graph of the colloidal solution of AgNPs was measured at 420 nm wavelength. According to these results, it could be concluded that the proteins produced by fungus P. chrysogenum MF318506 in solution for capping of AgNPs are stable in alkaline conditions but not in acidic conditions. These results agree with (El-Rafie et al., 2010). The results also showed that under these fermentation conditions the dry weight and protein content were 0.23 g and 2.71 mg/50 ml reaction volume, respectively. Also it was noticed that the initial pH8 shifted to 7.1 at the end of the reaction.
By mixing the obtained fungal extract (the reducing and capping agent) with aqueous solution of AgNO3 the color changed from transparent to reddish brown, forming (AgNPs-1) (Fig. 2a) due to the reduction of silver ions and formation of nanoparticle that were indicated by TEM analysis. TEM micrographs of the silver nanoparticles, using different magnifications, showed that AgNPs were well distributed without aggregation, possessing a spherical shape. In addition, it was found that the particle size was ranged from 9.75 to 25.21 nm and their average is (16.58 � 5.80) (Fig. 2b). Seabra and Dur�an (2015) indicated that the proteins/biomolecules could play an important role in the preventing aggregation of nanoparticle and stabilization of the nanosystem also the presence of capping agents may improve the biocompatibility of biogenic nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Effect of inoculum size and incubation period
sections.text:
Another two important factors affecting the fungal biomass and
A.A. Abd El Aty et al.
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592
protein production were the inoculum size and incubation period. The results emphasized that the fermentation medium inoculated with two discs and incubated for 4 days was the best for AgNPs biosynthesis. Under these fermentation conditions the dry weight and protein content were increased to be 0.48 g and 3.49 mg/50 ml, respectively. While the final pH changed to 6.96 and the maximum absorbance peaks of
UV–visible spectra was observed at 440 nm (AgNPs-2) (Fig. 3a). In addition to UV–Vis spectra the TEM image recorded from the silver nanoparticle film showed different sizes of spherical particles in ranges from 3.68 to 22.9 nm and their average is (11.19 � 8.41 nm) (Fig. 3b).
A.A. Abd El Aty et al.
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592

sections.heading: 3.3. Response surface methodology (RSM) application
sections.text:
The reaction conditions including, concentration of silver nitrate solution and pH value of the reaction were studied to control biogenesis of silver nano-size and accelerate the reduction of metal ions in a much lesser time from 5 days to 6 h, which is better than finding of Honary et al. (2013) who prepared AgNPs after 24 h of reaction using Penicillium citrinum supernatant and 1 mM aqueous AgNO3 solution. Obtained results was important to solve the problem of long reduction time, and more favorable for the industrial applications.
Two–factors–5–levels central composite design was used to achieve all possible combinations of input variable that are able to affect the response (AgNPs biosynthesis) within the region of 3-D Space (Fig. 4). CCD of Response Surface Methodology (RSM) was employed to study the effect of metal concentration and pH value on AgNPs biosynthesis from P. chrysogenum MF318506 with respect UV–vis absorbance in range from 400 to 450 nm, and to identify the most prominent interaction between significant variables for AgNPs production.
(Table 1) showed the levels of the two parameters along with AgNPs UV-absorbance as the response. The highest response, 3.00 was found at the center point (runs1, 4, 6, 7&13) where the concentration of the metal and pH were 3 and 10, respectively. On the other hand, the lowest response was found at run 12, where the pH was very low and not suitable for nano silver biosynthesis.
Results also indicated that the high metal concentration as shown in runs (3, 8, 10& 9) not appropriate with the high pH values therefore, the samples become turbid after time mainly due to protein precipitation. whereas the low metal concentrations (0.172 and 1 mM) are more suitable with high pH (8,12& 10) as indicated by their color and absorbance peaks of UV–visible spectra in runs (2, 5& 11), respectively (Figs. 5 and 6). These results agree with (El-Rafie et al., 2012) who indicated that the highest stability of AgNPs is attained at high alkaline conditions (pH 10–12). Du et al. (2015) reported the synthesis of extracellular AgNPs by using the cell filtrate of Penicillium oxalicum at
different pH values under light radiation. The average size of AgNPs was found at 4 nm with good dispersion and high stability when pH value was at 12.0. at this pH.
According to the analysis of variance (ANOVA), the quadratic model was founded to be significant at “Prob > F” less than 0.0500. The “RSquared” of 0.8055 is in reasonable agreement with the “Adj R-Squared” of 0.6665, which advocates for high significance of the model (Table 2). The R2 (0.8894) value of Box-Behnken design (BBD) applied to optimize Penicillium citrinum AgNPs similar to our results, that indicated a good correlation between the predicted and observed values Barabadi et al. (2019b).
The relation between the selected parameters and each response was established using a second order polynomial equation in terms of Actual Factors:
Absorbance ¼ 28.89011 þ 1.01442 � AgNO 3þ5.90869 � pHþ5.00000E003 � AgNO3*pH-0.10948 � AgNO32-0.29405 � p H2
All the previous results indicated that the central composite design was very accurate and applicable for determination of the best metal concentration and pH value suitable for well dispersed AgNPs biosynthesis as shown with the TEM analysis of the selected samples (Runs 2, 5 and 11). Our target agreed with Barabadi et al. (2019b) who applied the response surface methodology (RSM) of Box-Behnken design (BBD), to optimize the average diameter size of Penicillium citrinum AgNPs with the reduction of time and cost, depending on the effective factors of AgNO3 concentration and pH of solution.
Our findings explained that the fungal extract of locally isolated P. chrysogenum MF318506 can be applied as good reducing and capping agent for nano-silver biosynthesis, under good statistically controlled conditions of central composite (CCD). On the other hand, Barabadi et al. (2019a) Remarkably, 25 Penicillium species for biosynthesis of NPs. Notably, silver NPs with 70.76% of the studies were the first predominant which produced by exploiting Penicillium species. Significantly, among the studies that explored applications of NPs, most of them investigated antimicrobial efficacy of BM-NPs. Moreover, a hefty 91.22% studies reported spherical NPs, while only 8.77% refers to other morphologies. Furthermore, pharmaceutical potentials of BM-NPs were discussed in details.

sections.heading: 3.4. Characterization of controlled biosynthesized silver nanoparticles
sections.text:
Results indicated that among of 13 runs of CCD, the runs 2, 5 and 11 were selected as the best UV–visible absorbance spectra in range from 400 to 470 nm (Fig. 5). The absorption spectrum of spherical silver nanoparticles of Run 2 presented a maximum peak at 425 nm wavelength and the suspension color is pale yellow, where the nanoparticle formed with conditions of Run 5 showed a maximum peak at 425 nm wavelength and pale brown color, on the other hand, Run 11 has dark brown color with maximum absorbance peak at 470 as seen in (Figs. 5 and 6). Loiseau et al. (2019) reported that the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) is responsible for the bright color of the nanoparticle colloidal suspensions.
In Fig. (7), TEM measurements of the selected runs showed different sizes. TEM image of Run 2 confirms AgNPs were well dispersed without aggregation. The average particle size is around (9.74 � 5.23 nm) in range from 2.83 to 17.17 nm diameter. The diameter and the shape of Run 5 AgNPs were all shown to be spherical uniform and small sized in range from 2.68 to 7.12 nm with average of (5.26 � 1.66 nm). Nano size of Run 11 showed in range from 3.59 to 9.25 nm with average of (6.30 � 2.19 nm). These results partly agree with (Abd El Aty and Ammar, 2016).
FTIR spectrum of silver nanoparticles and fungal extract was analyzed to detect the functional groups which involved in synthesizing process. Results obtained in (Fig. 8) indicated that there is a higher matching in characteristic beaks among the fungal extract and
Results are represented by means of three replicates.
A.A. Abd El Aty et al.
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592
investigated samples (2,5 and 11). FTIR analyses revealed the appearance of distinctive bands at 1639.2, 1494.56, 1461.78, 1424.17, 3459.67, 3238.86 cm-1, correspond to the binding vibrations of amide I and amide II of protein, with N–H stretching’s. While the 2079.85 and 1874.47 cm 1 represents C–H stretching vibration. The bands obtained at 1314.25, 1235.18 and 1192 cm 1 can be assigned to C–N stretching vibrations of aliphatic and aromatic amines, respectively. That’s directly indicate the role of proteins as reducing and stabilizing agent.
DLS analysis showed the particle size means were 35.2, 28.95 and 38.40 nm of Run 2, 5 and 11, respectively. The zeta potential endows stability of nanoparticles and surface charge. The zeta potential was found to be -22.3, -200.0 and -81.7 mV of Run 2, 5 and 11, respectively. Baker et al. (2005) mentioned that when the zeta potential value positions between 30 and 50 mV, it specifies good stability of nano particles. The high negative value substantiates the repulsion between the particles and thereby increases the stability of the AgNP’s.

sections.heading: 3.5. Application experiments
sections.text: Several of applications of nanomaterials take advantage of the engineering of AgNPs plasmonic response that depends on their size, shape, dielectric environment, and on mutual electromagnetic interactions among particles in close proximity (Ren and Tilley, 2007). LSPR is the consequence of the confinement of the electric field, within a small metallic sphere whose radius is much smaller than the wavelength (Catherine and Olivier, 2017). This property can be tuned by controlling parameters such as shape, size, uniformity and surface coating (Loiseau et al., 2019), and is often used for biosensing applications in the field of biology, biomedicine and biochemistry.

sections.heading: 3.5.1. Antibacterial and antifungal effects
sections.text:
The antimicrobial properties of all silver nanoparticles synthesized using P. chrysogenum MF318506 protein under different conditions (AgNPs-1, AgNPs-2) and the selected runs from CCD (Run 2, Run 5 and Run 11) were studied using the agar diffusion method (Mohamed et al., 2017).
As mentioned previously by (Perelshtein et al., 2008; Martínez-Casta~n�on et al., 2008). the results in (Table 3) and (Fig. 9) indicated that, AgNPs-1 with particles size ranged from 9.75 to 25.21 nm has inhibitory activity against Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria measure about 20 and 21 mm respectively, and antifungal effect against the filamentous fungi in range from (18 to 19 mm). The ultrafine particles of AgNPs-2 with size ranged from 3.68 to 22.9 nm showed good antimicrobial activities better than AgNPs-1 against all tested strains, IZD in range from 13 to 23 mm diameter, except C. albicans able to resist all biosynthesized nanosilver.
Out of the three runs selected from CCD, Run 11 (particles size in range from 3.59 to 9.25 nm) has the best antibacterial effect (IZD 22 and 23 mm), and showed good antifungal activity against the unicellular yeast fungus C. tropicalis ATCC750 (15 mm) and the filamentous fungi, F. solani NRC15 and A. niger NRC53 (22 and 21 mm, respectively). The antifungal activity of AgNPs is mainly due to its effects on the fungal mycelia and by targeting the yeast cell membranes and disrupting membrane potential (Kim et al., 2009).
Run 2 showed antibacterial effect (with IZD of 16 and 20 mm) to some extend similar to its antifungal effect (with IZD of 15 and 21 mm). On the other hand, Run 5 has only inhibitory activity against the filamentous fungus A. niger NRC53 and F. solani NRC15 with IZD of 11 and 13 mm, respectively. The authors Morones et al. (2005) confirm our results, that the antimicrobial activity of AgNPs depends on their particles nano-size. In the same context Balachandar et al. (2019) showed good antibacterial activity of AgNPs biosynthesized from stem extract of Phyllanthus pinnatus against Vibrio cholera and Shigella flexneri. And another study of Kanagamani et al. (2019) explored the synthesis of AgNPs using Kleinia grandiflora leaf extract (KGLE) with significant antimicrobial efficacy against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Aspergillus
niger, that indicate the biological activity mainly depends on the particles, shape and size not on the source. So we noticed that smaller particles have a large surface area in touch with the bacterial and fungal cells, and can diffuse or penetrate a bacterial cell membrane easily and inhibit its growth by interfering in the natural metabolism processes or interface with the biomolecules such as DNA, lipids and proteins lead to microbial death.

sections.heading: 3.5.2. Cytotoxicity effect against different cancer cell lines
sections.text:
The broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity of silver is well known. Moreover, many researches have presented the potential use of AgNPs as anticancer agents due to their important antiangiogenic properties (Raghunandan et al., 2011; Chen et al., 2007). The cytotoxic effect of 5 samples against two human cancer cells HCT-116 and MCF-7 were investigated (Table 4). Cultures of different cell lines were treated with AgNPs first at one concentration of 100 μg/ml and the results showed one sample (Run 2) possessed moderate cytotoxic effect against colon cancer (HCT-116) and breast cancer (MCF-7) cell lines (43.5% and 51.5%, respectively), on the other hand, the rest samples showed weakly cytotoxic effect against cancer cell lines tested. It was elucidated that AgNPs can be uptake by cells through diffusion or endocytosis mechanisms including macropinocytosis, clathrin-mediated endocytosis, fluid phase endocytosis, and PI3/Akt mediated endocytosis causing cell damage due to excessive generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) including the superoxide radical (O-2) and H2O2, impairment in mitochondrial function, along with activation of signaling pathways inhibiting cell proliferation (Zhang et al., 2016).
The impact of silver nanoparticles against human colon adenocarcinoma was previously reported by Basu et al. (2015). In addition, Yehia and Al-Sheikh (2014) showed that silver nanoparticles has potential anticancer activity against MCF-7 (breast cancer) cell lines. From other biological sources Moteriya and Chanda (2018) investigated the genotoxicity of phytosynthesized AgNPs with an average size of 8 nm against normal human lymphocytes. No genotoxicity was found up to 50 ug, but fragmented DNA was observed at 200 ug. AgNPs with an average size of 49.98 nm synthesized via a fungus-mediated method caused DNA damage in NCI-H460 cells in a time-dependent manner at 2–20 ug.
Dose response study: The data presented in (Table 5) showed sample of Run 2 has highest cytotoxic activity against colon cancer and breast cancer cell lines with IC50 values (106.9 and 90.3 ug/ml μg/ml, respectively), this result indicated that the maximum cytotoxic effect of Run 2 showed 50% reduction in cell viability upon treatment with highest dose (100ug/ml). Nanoparticles with their small size (around 9.74 � 5.23 nm) are able to interact with larger biological molecules both intra and extracellular and they are internalized inside mammalian cells by uptake mechanisms as endocytosis. In this way, Liu et al. (2010) showed that nanoparticles (NPs) introduce a number of possibilities for treatment and diagnosis of cancer.
The most active samples which possessing high anticancer activity (�40) have been further tested for their cytotoxicity on human normal cell line HFB4 to evaluate their safety on normal cells. The data presented in (Table 6) showed, the selected sample showed weakly cytotoxic effect (33.6%) against normal melanocyte cell line (HFB4), this value means that the selected sample is more cytotoxic to the tumor cell lines as compared with the normal cell line, where Barabadi et al. (2019c) indicated that a recent 2018 meta-analysis data of cytotoxicity of biogenic MNPs in cancer cell lines was 9 times higher than that in normal cell lines, indicating much greater MNP cytotoxicity in cancer cell lines. Significant toxic effects of biogenic AgNPs with inhibitory concentration of 50% in breast cancer cell lines explained by Barabadi et al. (2019d) who expected that biogenic AgNPs may emerge as potential breast cancer therapeutic agents alone or in combination with FDA-approved anti-cancer drugs in the near future.
A.A. Abd El Aty et al.
Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 25 (2020) 101592

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Green synthetic approach for synthesis of AgNPs using fungal extracts offers a numbers of benefits of eco-friendliness and affinity in pharmaceuticals and other biomedical applications. Therefore, this study focused on the use of the novel fungal strain Penicillium chrysogenum MF318506 for biosynthesis of nano-silver. Two–factors–5–levels central composite design of RSM was applied to achieve all possible combinations of input variable that are able to affect the shape and size of nanoparticles. Several characterization analyses were applied to confirm the biosynthesis of nanoparticles including, the UV visible spectrum at the absorption range of 400–450 nm, HR-TEM analysis which showed the size, shape and crystal lattice structure of the synthesized particles. In addition, the FTIR spectrum and size particles diffraction analysis (DLS) has been applied. The biosynthesized nanoparticles of different sizes obtained from Run 2, Run 5 and Run 11 showed different effects against panel of different Gram positive and negative bacteria and fungi. The cytotoxic efficacy of the all prepared samples against HCT-116 and MCF-7 carcinoma was evaluated and Run 2 has the highest cytotoxic activity against colon cancer and breast cancer cell lines with IC50 values (106.9 and 90.3 μg/ml, respectively).
Declaration of competing interest
There is no conflict of interests regarding the publication of this paper.

referenceMentions.context: This field of science is making a valuable impact in the life science, specially biotechnology and biomedical science (Gan and Li, 2012).

Metal nanoparticles (MNP) introduce unique physical, chemical, electronic, and antimicrobial properties which make them suitable for their application in many fields including biosensing (Habouti et al., 2010), photonics (Hu and Chan,
2004), electronics (Alshehri et al., 2012), antimicrobials, anticancer (Salata, 2004; Chen et al.
, 2012), antimicrobials, anticancer (Salata, 2004; Chen et al., 2014) and in the biomedical fields for drug delivery and targeting (Cole et al.
, 2012), antimicrobials, anticancer (Salata, 2004; Chen et al., 2014) and in the biomedical fields for drug delivery and targeting (Cole et al.
, 2014) and in the biomedical fields for drug delivery and targeting (Cole et al., 2011; Sakamoto et al., 2010; Seigneuric et al., 2010).

Silver nanoparticles are seemed to be one of the most valuable nanoparticles, that have been applied widely in different biomedical fields such as, cancer therapy, antimicrobial agent, anti-inflammatory factor and the delivery of drugs (Moghaddam et al., 2015; Vijayakumara et al., 2019).

Metal nanoparticles are commonly synthesized via the reduction of metal salts in a solution (Zhang et al., 2011) or the formation of metal atom aggregates by the heating or vaporization of a metal in inert gas or vacuum (Tien et al.
, 2011) or the formation of metal atom aggregates by the heating or vaporization of a metal in inert gas or vacuum (Tien et al., 2008).
Size-controlled Ag NPs are also synthesized using new environment-friendly synthesis techniques (Mori et al., 2011).

It was elucidated that AgNPs can be uptake by cells through diffusion or endocytosis mechanisms including macropinocytosis, clathrin-mediated endocytosis, fluid phase endocytosis, and PI3/Akt mediated endocytosis causing cell damage due to excessive generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) including the superoxide radical (O-2) and H2O2, impairment in mitochondrial function, along with activation of signaling pathways inhibiting cell proliferation (Zhang et al., 2016).

metadata.abstractText: Biogenesis of metal nanoparticles draws significant attention due to environment eco-friendly and sustainable methods. Locally isolated Penicillium chrysogenum MF318506 free from mycotoxins was selected as candidate for bio-synthesis of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs). The response surface methodology (RSM) of central composite design (CCD) was applied to control the biosynthesis of silver nano-size and activity depending on the pH of the reaction mixture and AgNO3 concentration. Changing conditions in the design showed different nano-sizes with different antimicrobial and cytotoxic activities. The best conditions for biosynthesis of biologically active AgNPs could be attained using the low metal concentrations (0.172 and 1.0 mM) with high pH values (8, 12&10) after 6 h incubation in dark conditions. The controlled nanoparticles were studied and characterized by UV–visible spectrophotometry and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). From this study we have concluded that the statistically controlled silver nano-size from Penicillium chrysogenum MF318506 can be utilized as a novel good candidate in biomedical research.
